Local officials in the southern Ukrainian region of Kherson have described their shock and disbelief as Russian troops attacking from Crimea overwhelmed their defences.

Early on the morning of February 24, Russian soldiers were deployed from occupied Crimea. In a matter of hours, they reached Nova Kakhovka, in the centre of the Kherson region, and nearby Oleshek. By mid-morning, the Russians had seized Nova Kakhovka‚Äôs Kakhovskaya hydroelectric power station and captured the North Crimean Canal in the neighbouring city of Tavriysk.

Municipal officials complained about the lack of communication with the regional and state authorities. Tavriysk mayor Mykola Rizak said that he immediately informed the leadership of the Kherson regional state administration.

‚ÄúI told them about the capture of the channel, but they did not believe it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd I have a question: how could Russian tanks, Grads and armoured personnel carriers pass from Armyansk to Tavriysk in four hours? Where is our first echelon of defence [or] the second, about which the regional authorities told us many times and reassured us that everything will be fine? Where are they?‚Äù

There was heavy fighting in the area of ‚Äã‚Äãthe Kakhovskaya hydroelectric power station - which was occupied by Russian forces - and on the outskirts of Kherson. Wounded Russian soldiers were taken to the Novokakhovskaya city hospital and there were also civilian casualties, including at least three people killed due to shelling in Oleshki. On February 24, on a highway near the village of Tsukury in the Tavrian region, a Russian armoured personnel carrier hit a car. The passenger died at the scene, and the driver remains in critical condition.

In the late afternoon of February 25, the head of the regional state administration Gennady Laguta announced the loss of control over the Antonovsky Bridge, the main crossing to Kherson across the Dnieper from the city of Oleshki.

‚ÄúThe enemy overcame the city‚Äôs defences with great force and heavy losses,‚Äù he posted on Facebook. ‚ÄúWe urge you to remain calm and not panic. The regional leadership is making every effort to maintain law and order and save lives. The situation remains tense, but we promise to do everything possible to resolve it.‚Äù

Laguta said that the situation in the Kherson region remained tense.

‚ÄúIn the Genichesk region, all state structures came under the control of the invaders,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúRussian [military] equipment stands in Genichesk itself; on its outskirts there are checkpoints with Russian troops. They check those entering whether they belonging to the Armed Forces of Ukraine.‚Äù

Fighting continued in Nova Kakhovka. At about noon on February 25, Russian troops seized the administrative building of the Novokakhovka city council. However, a few hours later, the soldiers left the city council building, according to Nova Kakhovka mayor Volodymyr Kovalenko.

‚ÄúThey negotiated with me and my deputies,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey listened to our wishes, among which were to keep tanks and armoured vehicles off the city‚Äôs streets. After that, they removed the security from the building and departed in an unknown direction.‚Äù

Kovalenko said that he was working day and night to try and keep the city functioning, with all communication with the regional authority lost. Others fear a power vaccum, with some local counsellors having evacuated and the police, state security service and prosecutor's office not functioning in either Novo Kakhovka or Kakhovka.

To prevent looting, Kakhovka was patrolled by the local volunteers, and 20 representatives of the municipal security organisations helped maintain calm in Nova Kakhova.

‚ÄúRegarding weapons, we had only two [non-lethal] pistols and the aim to prevent widespread looting,‚Äù said local resident Sergiy Tsigipa, one of the organisers of the local defence battalion.

‚ÄúWe're in hell here,‚Äù said Lyudmila Annas, the village of Vesyoloye. ‚ÄúSince seven in the morning on February 25, they have been bombing, there are many Russian tanks and armoured personnel carriers in the village. They go everywhere: along the streets, gardens of local residents. There is a lot of Russian military equipment on the village sports fields, a whole military unit of them stands nearby. Hot shrapnel falls on the adjacent areas. People are afraid to leave the house.‚Äù

Berislav mayor Oleksandr Shapovalov told IWPR that the entire area had been left without power.

‚ÄúWe had an electricity blackout in the town and in all the surrounding villages. There were disruptions in supplying bread to the local hospital, however later on the 25th we started to resolve these issues.‚Äù

Roads were damaged in other large communities of the Kakhovskya district.

‚ÄúLocal authorities are now trying to repair these damages,‚Äù said local mayor Maksim Kolokot.

The swift progress of the invasion at first shocked the local authorities of the Kherson oblast. Mayors and local officials complained about the lack of communication with the district authorities and the lack of access to key information on the first day of the war.

For now, major infrastructure remains under the control of Russia.

‚ÄúThey check everyone incoming to the city whether they are members of the Ukraine army or not,‚Äù said Genadi Laguta, head of the Kherson oblast. ‚ÄúThe Kahovskaya hydro power station is under the control of the enemy. Large military machinery also moved towards Berislav district as well as to Skadovskaya.‚Äù

Summary

Russian forces have launched an invasion of Ukraine, with troops entering the country from the east, from Belarus in the north, and Crimea in the south.

Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a televised address, announcing a military operation to demilitarise and ‚Äòde-nazify‚Äô Ukraine.

Ukraine‚Äôs air defence systems have largely been disabled.

Multiple cities across the country have been struck by missiles and artillery shells, including Kyiv, Odessa, Kharkiv, and Mariupol.

Ukraine has declared a state of emergency and closed its airspace to all civilian traffic.

Road and rail routes out of the country are largely congested due to the number of people attempting to evacuate.

Situation

Early on 24 February, Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a televised address to the nation during which he announced the commencement of a military operation to demilitarise and ‚Äòde-nazify‚Äô Ukraine. President Putin warned other countries against inhibiting Russia‚Äôs actions in Ukraine, stating that Russia‚Äôs actions would lead to ‚Äúconsequences that you have never faced in your history‚Äù. While Vladimir Putin was still talking, multiple explosions were reported around the Ukrainian city of Mariupol. Following this, explosions targeted areas of Kyiv, Kharkiv, Odessa, Ivano-Frankivsk, and more. The Russian forces subsequently launched a campaign to disable Ukraine‚Äôs air defence systems, primarily targeting military airbases.



Following the initial stages, columns of Russian ground forces entered Ukrainian territory from the east, from Belarus in the north, and from Crimea in the south. Armed clashes have occurred between Ukrainian and Russian forces in multiple areas of the country. The use of thermobaric, cruise and ballistic missile systems has been documented, primarily against military structures. One of the heaviest confrontations is believed to be around Antonov International Airport in Hostomel, approximately 25 kilometres northwest of central Kyiv. Videos have been shared online showing Russian attack helicopters surrounding the airport, with large columns of smoke emerging from the site.

Ground forces are also believed to be engaging in combat at the airport. The level of fighting in close proximity to Kyiv has raised concerns that Russian forces will attempt to capture the capital city in the coming hours. Heavy fighting has also been recorded around the Antonovskiy Bridge, leading into Kherson, and Russian forces are believed to have entered the city. Valerii Zaluzhnyi, the Chief of Staff of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, has alleged that four ballistic missiles have been fired from Belarusian territory in the southwest direction.

The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, announced that Russian forces are attempting to gain control of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, calling the action ‚Äúa declaration of war against the whole of Europe‚Äù. Although the primary targets appear to be military bases and infrastructure, civilian casualties have been documented on several occasions. A video has surfaced showing a fighter jet firing at least two rockets towards a civilian housing complex. The exact figures of civilian and military fatalities are unavailable.



The previous night, Ukraine‚Äôs Verkhovna Rada approved a 30-day state of emergency to be imposed at midnight. The state of emergency allows the country‚Äôs authorities to restrict freedom of movement, inspect vehicles, "strengthen the protection of public order", restrict the sale of alcohol and weapons, prohibit public gatherings, impose curfews, and regulate broadcast outlets. Then, following the invasion, the Ukrainian government imposed martial law and closed the country‚Äôs airspace. Currently, civilian flights are disallowed from operating services to and from Ukraine, limiting evacuation options. Multiple roads leading west have become heavily congested, due to the volume of people attempting to evacuate the country. Likewise, videos surfaced today showing large crowds queuing outside Kyiv‚Äôs main railway station (Pasazhyrskyi), implying that rail options are also congested.

Russia‚Äôs actions have been met with widespread international condemnation. The United Kingdom‚Äôs Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, delivers a televised address during which he denounced Russia‚Äôs actions, labelling President Putin as a ‚Äúdictator‚Äù, and stated that a ‚Äúmassive package‚Äù of sanctions will be imposed, asserting ‚Äúwe will do whatever it takes‚Äù to support Ukraine. Moldova and Latvia have both declared a state of emergency, while the Finnish Prime Minister, Sanna Marin, has announced that her country is ready to apply for NATO membership, ‚Äúif it becomes a matter of national security‚Äù. Jens Stoltenberg, the Secretary General of NATO, has labelled the invasion as a ‚Äúbrutal act of war‚Äù and announced that the bloc is increasing its presence in the eastern European members and heightening the readiness of the NATO Response Force. At an emergency United Nations Security Council meeting, each member was largely critical of the Russian invasion, and the Ukrainian ambassador to the United Nations, Sergiy Kyslytsya, stated that Russia has declared war on Ukraine.



Analysis and Implications

The Russian authorities are believed to have several objectives in conducting its invasion of Ukraine. Primarily, it is understood that Russia is seeking to remove the incumbent Ukrainian authorities from power. Russia views the post-2014 Ukrainian governments as a threat to its national security, hence the operation to demilitarise the country. It remains to be seen whether Russia will annex any more of Ukraine‚Äôs territory. However, it is probable that if Russia is successful in removing Ukraine‚Äôs administration, it will install a new pro-Russian government. In such an event, it is possible that an insurgency will be carried out by the Ukrainian population, something that is being actively encouraged by the country‚Äôs armed forces.

President Zelensky announced that Ukraine will give weapons to anyone willing to defend it, stating that people should ‚Äúbe ready to support Ukraine in the squares of our cities‚Äù. If this occurs, it is possible that Russian troops could remain in Ukraine for an extended period to quell any pockets of resistance. Already, videos have surfaced showing troops from Rosgvardiya deployed inside Ukrainian territory, specifically, in Henichesk, situated in the Kherson Oblast. Rosgvardiya constitutes Russia‚Äôs domestic armed forces who have previously been deployed to Belarus in order to quell protest activities. This suggests that the Russian government is planning a long-term operation in Ukraine.



The invasion of Ukraine is already having impacts on global financial markets, and sanctions are likely to worsen the situation. In the immediate aftermath of the invasion‚Äôs commencement, the value of the Russian rouble fell by approximately 20 percent, before achieving a slight recovery. The price of oil has reached its highest level since 2014, at 105 USD per barrel. The FTSE 100 share index fell this morning by 3 percent, London-listed Russian company Sberbank‚Äôs share price fell by 61 percent and Gazprom‚Äôs fell by 28 percent. Wheat prices have also increased sharply, to approximately 390 USD per tonne, which is thought to be the largest price rise for nine years. The full scale of economic impact remains to be seen, but fuel and gas prices are expected to rise.



The risk to traveller safety is critical, civilian fatalities have been reported on multiple occasions and there is no guarantee that fighting will happen exclusively outside civilian zones. Worsening the risk, are the limited availability of transport options. With all civilian flights suspended alongside road and rail options being heavily congested, it is likely that difficulties will arise when attempting to evacuate the country. Ukrainian authorities have set up bomb shelters in the major cities, including the capital, many of which are in underground railway stations.

The United States Embassy to Ukraine currently advises that people should shelter-in-place. Both sides have accused the other of spreading lies and launching disinformation campaigns, indicating that verifiable information is limited, possibility impeding the ability of travellers to keep abreast of the current situation.





Advice

Defer all non-essential travel to Ukraine.

Ensure that travel passports and travel documents are up to date and regularly review possible departure options.

Where applicable, travellers in Ukraine should familiarise themselves with plans to evacuate the country and/or implement robust security measures.

Regularly monitor reputable national and international news reports for situational updates over the coming days and weeks, keeping in mind the rifeness of disinformation campaigns.

Timeline - February 24, 2022

All times UTC



1525: Mayor of Kyiv announces city-wide curfew from 2200-0700 local time.



1426: Video posted on social media purports to show Russian military vehicles crossing the Antonovsky bridge and entering Kherson city, a suburb of Antonivka, located about 451 kilometers (280 miles) south-southeast of Kyiv.



1410: Reports emerge that a hospital in Vuhledar, Donetsk Oblast, has been struck by Russian munitions, allegedly causing four civilian fatalities and injuring six others.



1400: Videos emerge showing civilian fatalities and structural damages in Mariupol.



1355: Reuters reports that an unidentified missile has struck southern Kyiv, causing damage to structures. Details of possible injuries have not been specified.



1350: U.S. President Joe Biden convenes National Security Council to discuss the situation in Ukraine. POTUS to deliver update on the Russia-Ukraine situation at 1730 UTC.



1340: Videos surface appearing to show Rosgvardiya troops in Heniches‚Äôk, in the Kherson Oblast.



1340: The Ukrainian Ministry of Defense announces that four ballistic missiles have been launched from the territory of Belarus in the southwestern direction.



1335: The Czech Republic announces it is suspending the granting of visas to Russian citizens.



1330: The Ministry of Defense of Ukraine reports that as of 1500 local time, fighting is continuing along the entire line of contact and that three Russian tanks have been destroyed.



1330: The Russian armed forces claim to have destroyed 74 objects of Ukrainian military infrastructure and additionally claim that 14 Ukrainian soldiers have surrendered in the Donbas region.



1320: Air raid sirens are sounded in Kyiv.



1315: Videos emerge purporting to show shelling in the village of Trypilla, 40 kilometers (25 miles) south of central Kyiv.



1310: The Ukrainian State Border Guard stated that its forces are engaged with Russian troops on the outskirts of Sumy.



1310: Videos surface showing ten Ukrainian T-64BV tanks in the Kherson region, all of which have been destroyed.



1300: Deputies evacuated from Ukraine‚Äôs Verkhovna Rada in Kyiv.



1300: Images surface showing a Russian helicopter being shot down over Vyshhorod.



1255: Videos surface showing large explosions at the airbase near Melitopol‚Äô.



1240: Reports surface of civilians in Kharkiv unloading firearms from a vehicle, preparing to fight Russian soldiers.



1240: Reports surface stating that a Ukrainian military aircraft has crashed near Kyiv, killing 14 people who were onboard. It is unclear if the aircraft was shot down or not.



1230: Russian forces are believed to be in control of Antonov International Airport (IATA: GML) in Homostel‚Äô, near Kyiv.



1210: NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg says alliance has no plans to deploy forces to Ukraine.



1205: Reports surface of Russian special forces conducting operations in Kyiv, particularly in the government areas.



1200: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson delivers a televised address, during which he condemns Russia‚Äôs actions and states that a ‚Äúmassive package‚Äù of sanctions will be imposed on Russia, and that the country ‚Äúwill do whatever it takes‚Äù to support Ukraine.



1155: Reports surface of Russian and Ukrainian fighter jets engaging in combat around Kyiv.



1135: Videos surface taken on the E40, near Kharkiv, showing several destroyed Russian vehicles alongside one dead soldier.



1130: Reports surface of burning grain silos in Uman‚Äô, Cherkasy Oblast.



1125: NATO Secretary General, Jens Stoltenberg, delivers a live speech during which he states that NATO is initiating its active defense plans, allowing a deployment of the NATO Response Force.



1115: Numerous Russian attack helicopters are seen flying over Homostel‚Äô in the Kyiv Oblast, under 30 kilometers (18 miles) from the center of the capital city.



1100: Media sources report seeing smoke rising over the headquarters of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine in Kyiv.



1100: Russian Mi-24/35M and Mi-28N attack helicopters are seen flying over the Kakhova hydroelectric plant on the Dnieper river.



1100: Russian-state controlled media reports that two civilian cargo ships have been struck by Ukrainian missiles in the Sea of Azov, no other official confirmation has been received.



1100: Ukrainian authorities claim to have shot down three Russian helicopters near Antonov International Airport (IATA: GML).



1040: Ukrainian authorities claim to have shot down a total of five Russian aircraft.



1025: Belarus announces large parts of its airspace are closed to civilian traffic for an indefinite period.



0955: President Zelensky announces that Ukraine is severing diplomatic ties with Russia, and that the government will give weapons to anyone willing to defend Ukraine, stating ‚Äúbe ready to support Ukraine in the squares of our cities‚Äù.



0900: Moldova declares a state of emergency and closes its airspace; flights en route to the country are being diverted.



0830: The General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine issues an update stating that Ukrainian forces successfully halted the advance of Russian forces in the city of Chernihiv.



0805: Poland, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania invoke NATO Article 4 to table concerns over threats to territorial integrity, political independence, and/or security with Alliance members.



0750: Journalists report hearing sirens multiple times across Lviv, as authorities urged city residents to take cover.



0715: Video footage on social media shows Russian ground forces on the outskirts of Kharkiv city.



0709: Widespread mobile phone disruptions reported throughout Ukraine, including outages in Chernivtsi, Odesa, and Lviv oblasts.



0650: Video footage on social media shows significant traffic jams heading west from the center of Kyiv.



0605: President Charles Michel of the European Council and President Ursula von der Leyen of the European Commission issue statement condemning Russia‚Äôs military aggression and calling on Russia to ‚Äúimmediately cease the hostilities and withdraw its military from Ukraine.‚Äù EU member state leaders plan to hold an emergency summit on Thursday evening.



0600: Ukrainian authorities claim to have shot down up to five Russian planes and one helicopter in Luhansk, though such reports have subsequently been denied by Moscow.



0530: Explosion, large smoke plume filmed at Kherson International Airport (IATA: KHE) in Ukraine‚Äôs southern city of Kherson.



0450: CCTV shows Russian mechanized infantry units advance across the border from Veselovka, Belarus into Senkivka, Ukraine.



0445: The Ukrainian Interior Ministry claims that the invasion had already resulted in ‚Äúhundreds of casualties,‚Äù though no further details were specified.



0430: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy declared nationwide indefinite martial law amid the ongoing Russian invasion. The government has also urged all citizens to seek shelter from the Russian bombardment.



0300 - 0430: Initial explosions targeting Ukrainian infrastructure, primarily military installations, have occurred in various cities near Ukraine‚Äôs borders and in the capital city of Kyiv early Thursday morning. Explosions were reported in Berdyans'k, Bila Tserkva, Boryspil, Dnipro, Ivano-Frankivsk, Kharkiv, Kherson, Kramatorsk, Kyiv, Mariupol, Mykolaiv, and Odesa.



Cross-border incursion of Russian ground forces reported in Ukraine‚Äôs northeastern city of Kharkiv. Pro-Russian forces in the self-declared, breakaway republics of Luhansk and Donetsk advanced across the line of contact, reportedly seizing multiple villages including Horodyshche and Milove.



0300: Russian President Vladimir Putin announces the beginning of a ‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù in Ukraine. He proclaimed that Russia intends to ‚Äúdemilitarize‚Äù Ukraine, and called on the nation‚Äôs armed forces to surrender. Moments later, the Ukrainian Interior Ministry warned that the invasion had begun, with reports of explosions in multiple cities.

Ukraine Support Services

With ongoing tensions in Ukraine, Anvil is able to offer bespoke service packages to those who may have personnel in or around this region.

These service packages can include:

Intelligence Support in the form of daily situation updates, risk summaries and city/region specific awareness reports

Evacuation Consultation and Planning

Dedicated Security Assets in region

Medical Emergency Response Plans

In Country Expat Crisis Support

Speak with one of our experienced team directly on +44(0)20 7938 4221 (UK) or +1 (813) 514-6276 (US) for further details on the specialist support packages available.

article_text:
A Ukrainian soldier has been hailed as a hero for blowing himself up to destroy a bridge in an effort to stop Russian tanks from invading his country.

Marine battalion engineer Vitaly Skakun Volodymyrovych was deployed to the Henichesk bridge in the southern province of Kherson when the Russian tanks advanced, the Ukrainian military said on its Facebook page.

‚ÄúOn this difficult day for our country, when the Ukrainian people give way to the Russian occupiers in all directions, one of the hardest places on the map of Ukraine was the Crimean intersection, where one of the first enemies met a separate marine battalion,‚Äù according to the post.

Marine battalion engineer Vitaly Skakun Volodymyrovych blew himself up on a bridge to stop the Russians from advancing in Ukraine. Social media/ East2west News

When the battalion decided that the only way to block the armored column was by blowing up the bridge, Volodymyrovych volunteered to place mines on the span, the General Staff of the Armed Forces said.

And when he realized he had no time to get to safety, the brave soldier made the ultimate sacrifice on the bridge, which connected Russian-occupied Crimea and mainland Ukraine.

Volodymyrovych‚Äôs bravery slowed the Russian advance.

Volodymyrovych volunteered to place mines on the bridge. social media/ East2west News

‚ÄúAccording to his brothers in arms, Vitaly got in touch [with them] and said he was going to blow up the bridge. Immediately after an explosion rang out,‚Äù the military said.

‚ÄúOur brother was killed. His heroic act significantly slowed down the push of the enemy, allowing the unit to relocate and organize the defense,‚Äù the statement said.

Get the latest updates in the Russia-Ukraine conflict with The Post‚Äôs live coverage.

‚ÄúRussian invaders, know, under your feet the earth will burn! We will fight as long as we live! And as long as we are alive we will fight!‚Äù it added.

Military commanders said they planned to give Volodymyrovych a posthumous award for his ‚Äúheroic act.‚Äù

Vitaly Skakun Volodymyrovych made the ultimate sacrifice to halt the advancing Russians. General Staff of the Armed Force

The bridge connected Russian-occupied Crimea and mainland Ukraine.

More than 130 Ukrainian soldiers were killed battling Russian invaders on the first day of fighting.

As a result of his act of valor, the Russian forces were forced to take a longer route into the region, the US Sun reported.

More than 130 Ukrainian soldiers were killed on the first day of fighting after Russian forces stormed into the country, according to the outlet.

article_author: ['The Saker', 'Paul Greenwood', 'Ed Lytwak', 'Rhys Jaggar', 'Dmitry Orlov', 'Jean-Marie L.', 'Smidt Diuk', 'Richard Steven Hack', 'Charles Stegiel', 'Ian Gaskin']
article_text:
Day 2 of the Russian operation in the Ukraine ‚Äì OPEN THREAD

Today is a major day in the Russian military operation. Why?

Because Russian forces are now on the outskirts of many major Ukrainian cities. If yesterday was ‚Äústandoff weapons‚Äù day, today is the first day when Russian forces can now begin to degrade Ukrainian artillery dispositions, engage Ukie armor and break through Ukrainian fortifications. Today is also the last day for US PSYOPs to try to present a counter-narrative (Ukies heroically resisting, Russian dying in huge numbers, effective counter-attacks, etc.).

Yet we live in the smartphone with camera era and picture like this one tell the full story:

What you see in this picture are immense traffic jams of folks fleeing not Mariupol or Kramatorsk, but Kiev, the capital.

Here is a quick machine translated news update from Col. Cassad:

1. LDNR ‚Äì the positional nature of the fighting remains, with attempts by the LDNR armies to advance to the borders of the territories occupied by the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

2. The southern direction ‚Äì the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation retained control over the bridge over the Dnieper at Kherson, repulsing attempts of counterattacks by the Armed Forces of Ukraine.. Fighting in the Antonovsky Bridge area continues.

A New Kakhovka is also being held. Melitopol was taken this morning and the advance towards Berdyansk began.

3. Kharkiv direction ‚Äì fighting continues on the near approaches to Kharkov. Both sides are suffering losses in people and equipment.

4. Sumy direction ‚Äì the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation took Putivl and passing through Sumy (the battle at the airport continued there today), advanced to Konotop, surrounding the city. Today, attempts to take Akhtyrka continued in order to reach Kharkov from the west. There are Russian roadblocks on the Sumy-Kiev highway. There is an advance to Kiev and Chernihiv. (The APU repelled the attack of the Russian Armed Forces in the Chernihiv direction).

5. Kiev ‚Äì Gostomel airfield is held by paratroopers. The APU could not dislodge them from there. This morning, tank columns of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation broke through to the near approaches to Kiev and are close to establishing direct communication with the landing. The AFU is preparing a counterattack, stating that another landing will be thrown out in the Gostomel area today. The Pentagon says that Kiev will fall in the coming days. After 10 o‚Äôclock shooting was heard in the city. Also, according to the statement of the Armed Forces of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation, the landing was thrown to the west of Zhytomyr. The Armed Forces of Ukraine are actively undermining bridges on the approaches, trying to slow down the advance of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation,

6. In the morning, strikes continued on military facilities of the Armed Forces of Ukraine throughout the territory of Ukraine. A Su-27 of the Ukrainian Air Force was shot down over Kiev ‚Äì according to one version by the Russian air defense system, according to another ‚Äì by the Ukrainian ones. The downed ‚ÄúCaliber‚Äù fell on a residential building in Kiev, but there were no casualties. During the shelling of Gorlovka, a school was hit ‚Äì 2 teachers were killed.

7. The AFU launched a missile attack on the Millerovo airfield on the territory of the Russian Federation. Damage is reported at the airfield, but there are no losses in aircraft.

I now leave you with an open thread, please try to stick to FACTUAL INFORMATION and please refrain from prophecies about the future or stream of consciousness about the present.

One more thing: today Putin appealed to the Ukrainian soldiers and told them not to let the Banderistas to rule over them, he basically called for them to take power and negotiate with Russia. Ukie generals need to think hard about what they will do next.

I will try to post an analysis of the day later today.

Andrei

article_author: ['Bigg Chungus', 'Christian J. Chuba', 'Corrupt Shithole Of Ukropisstan', 'Michael Petrovich', "Dick Von Dast'Ard", 'George Palmer']
article_text:
Support SouthFront

As a result of the strikes of the Russian armed forces, 83 ground objects of the military infrastructure of Ukraine were put out of operation, including at least 11 airfields of the Ukrainian Air Force, 3 command posts, a base of the naval forces of Ukraine, as well as 18 radar stations of the S-300 and Buk -M1 anti‚Äìaircraft missile defense systems. Since the beginning of the military operation, two Ukrainian Su-27, two Su-24, one helicopter and four Bayraktar attack UAV have been shot down, according to the Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation

The moment of the fall of an aircraft in Vyshgorod was captured on the video. According to some reports it was a Russian helicopter.

The Ukrainian military transport AN-26 was shot down in the Kiev region. There were 14 people on board according to local reports.

In Eastern Ukraine, according to the Russian military officials, the soldiers of the Armed Forces of Ukraine avoid armed clashes and agree on the creation of exit corridors in the zone of the operation.

Resistance is mainly shown by armed detachments of nationalist paramilitary groups of Ukraine.

The DPR and LPR troops continue their counter-offensives against the UAF units with fire support from the Russian armed forces.

The Kievsky district of Donetsk is under heavy artillery fire.

Forces of the DPR have successfully advanced 7 km towards the village of Volnovakha in the area of Dokuchaevsk. Several settlements have been liberated, the UAF in this area are lost and disorganized.

In the Volnovakha direction, the DPR units, after a heavy battle, captured the settlements of Ignatovka and Nikolaevka.

At least, 14 soldiers of the Armed Forces of Ukraine surrendered on the DPR front lines. The Russian military command said that after taking their subscription to renounce hostilities, they would all be released.

As a result of pilot‚Äôs mistake, a Russian Su-25 attack aircraft crashed, the Russian Defense Ministry said. The pilot survived. According to local reports, the aircraft crashed in the Ostrogozhsky district.

The LPR forces overcame fierce resistance and advanced 1 km near the village of Stepovoye.

In the North-East, Russian tanks entered the city of Sumy.

Russian armored personnel carrier BTR-82A and destroyed Ukrainian BMP-1 in the Sumy region:

Military equipment left by the UAF near Sumy:

According to the administration of the Sumy region, the Ukrainian military has lost control over the Kiev-Moscow highway in the region. The highway is completely controlled by the Russian army up to the city of Baturin in the Chernihiv region.

Clashes were reported in the towns of Akhtyrka and Konotop, as well as on the approaches to Sumy. No civilians were injured.

Military equipment left by Russian forces:

The city of Kharkov was blocked by forces of the Group Z of the Russian military.

Locals welcomed the Russian tanks in the Kharkov region, joking and claiming: ‚ÄúHope our forces (Ukrainian) do not come back‚Äù.

In the Southern Ukraine, the Russian Armed Forces continue to move in the Kherson region, Russian troops have advanced more than 100 km.

The Russian Armed Forces entered the city of Kherson.

The Crimean grouping of Russian troops completely destroyed the tank brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine 5 kilometers from Kherson. Obviously, there are dead and wounded.

According to local reports, Russian forces are going to encircle the Odessa region and the town of Ochakov.

T-64 tanks of the Ukrainian army were destroyed on the Antonovsky Bridge in the vicinity of Kherson:

A powerful explosion at the Melitopol airfield was reported:

In Kiev, the Russian Armed Forces have established control over the airfield in the outskirts of the capital.

Russian Group V got through the defensive lines of the Armed Forces of Ukraine on the border with Belarus, took the airfield of Gostomel.

It is reported that the city of Gostomel, located 15 km from Kiev, was taken by the Russian Armed Forces. The consequences of an air raid by Russian army aviation on a military unit in Gostomel on the northwestern outskirts of Kiev:

In the eastern outskirts of Kiev, a military unit of the Armed Forces of Ukraine was burned near Brovary.

The building in which the 72nd center for information and psychological operations of the Armed Forces of Ukraine was deployed in Brovary near Kiev was destroyed.

The Chernobyl NPP is reportedly under the control of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation.

Su-27 of the Ukrainian Air Force was destroyed at the airfield near Zhytomyr:

Despite various reports by the MSM, Belorussia does not take part in the military operation in Ukraine, but Minsk is ready to support Russia in case of any aggression on its territory.

Kiev is spreading the fake news that two Russian soldiers were captured. The photo provided to support the claims was made at a winter time, there was no snow in Eastern Ukraine for at least two weeks.

According to open sources, the UAF have at least one Russian serviceman captured. The deaths of at least two Russian soldiers were confirmed by the videos. 4 servicemen of the LPR were reportedly captured. However, the claims are yet to be confirmed.

Russian troops do not target civilian infrastructure, residential buildings, as well as social facilities of the Ukrainian military garrisons, including barracks and residential buildings, in order to avoid casualties among Ukrainian military personnel and their family members.

Russian Defense Ministry Sergey Shoigu ordered to all unit commanders to treat Ukrainian servicemen with respect.

‚ÄúTaking into account the fact that the servicemen of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, unlike the nationalists, took the oath to the Ukrainian people and obeyed orders, treat them with respect. I ordered to work out the creation of safe corridors for the safe exit of Ukrainian servicemen who have laid down their arms from the areas of the operation to their families‚Äù

Rosyjskie si≈Çy zbrojne rozpoczƒô≈Çy dzia≈Çania ofensywne przeciwko Ukrainie. Artyleria lufowa i rakietowa ostrzela≈Çy pozycje obro≈Ñc√≥w, nap≈ÇywajƒÖ r√≥wnie≈º doniesienia o eksplozjach miƒôdzy innymi w Charkowie, Mariupolu, Berdia≈Ñsku nad Morzem Azowskim i w samym Kijowie. A≈º chcia≈Çoby siƒô sparafrazowaƒá Juliƒô Ryczer: Dnia dwudziestego czwartego lutego roku pamiƒôtnego wr√≥g napad≈Ç na Ukrainƒô z kraju sƒÖsiedniego.

Dzi≈õ tu≈º przed godzinƒÖ 4.00 czasu polskiego w rosyjskiej telewizji nadano orƒôdzie W≈Çadimira Putina. Podobnie jak wszystkie wcze≈õniejsze wystƒÖpienia, tak≈ºe i to mia≈Ço posmak propagandowy, a nie informacyjny. ZresztƒÖ prawdopodobnie nagrano je z wyprzedzeniem. Putin og≈Çosi≈Ç, ≈ºe Rosja przeprowadzi operacjƒô wojskowƒÖ w celu demilitaryzacji i denazyfikacji (!) Ukrainy oraz wezwa≈Ç ukrai≈Ñskich ≈ºo≈Çnierzy, aby z≈Ço≈ºyli bro≈Ñ i wr√≥cili do dom√≥w. W praktyce ca≈Çe jego przem√≥wienie stanowi≈Ço wypowiedzenie wojny.

Wcze≈õniej w≈Çadze samozwa≈Ñczych republik ludowych utworzonych pod egidƒÖ Kremla w Donbasie zwr√≥cili siƒô do Rosji z pro≈õbƒÖ o pomoc w odparciu rzekomej agresji ze strony Ukrai≈Ñc√≥w.Na marginesie mo≈ºna smutno skonstatowaƒá, ≈ºe harmonogram inwazji pokrywa≈Ç siƒô ‚Äì z tolerancjƒÖ plus/minus kilku dni ‚Äì bardzo dok≈Çadnie z ustaleniami NATO-wskich wywiad√≥w. Operacjƒô kinetycznƒÖ poprzedzi≈Ç zmasowany cyberatak ‚Äì w dw√≥ch osobnych falach ‚Äì na ukrai≈Ñskie rzƒÖdowe serwisy internetowe. WystƒÖpi≈Çy tak≈ºe zak≈Ç√≥cenia ≈ÇƒÖczno≈õci, w tym telefonii kom√≥rkowej.
